Fig. 7 Elucidating the structure-activity relationship of Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts towards CH3OH oxidation Suxin Yu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation Conceptualization Haoyuan Gu Methodology Investigation Data curation Qihang Wen Methodology Investigation Data curation Yi-Fan Han Supervision Resources Project administration Minghui Zhu Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology 130 Meilong Road Shanghai 200237 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, 130 Meilong Road, Shanghai 200237, China ⁎ Corresponding author. MnO2-based catalysts have been extensively utilized in the catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds due to their cost-effectiveness. In this study, a series of Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts with various contents were systematically investigated to reveal the structure-activity relationship during the CH3OH oxidation reaction, which was achieved using a series of characterizations. Bi could enter the MnO2 lattice and lead to the facile formation of oxygen vacancies, facilitating the generation of surface reactive oxygen species by O2 dissociation. With the increase of Bi, the activity showed a volcanic trend, and the Mn7.5Bi1Ox (T90 = 160 °C) exhibited the lowest apparent activation energy and optimal performance. CH3OH oxidation mechanism (CH3OH → methoxy species → formate species → CO2 and H2O) was revealed by in situ DRIFTS, and the last two oxidation processes were significantly sped up. Bi-doped MnO2 exhibited high H2O tolerance due to hydroxyl-assisted CH3OH chemisorption via hydrogen bonding and hydroxyl-assisted C-H activation of methoxy species with surface reactive oxygen species. These findings are beneficial for the rational design of metal-doped catalysts with rich oxygen vacancy defects for catalytic oxidation. Graphical Abstract Keywords CH3OH oxidation Manganese oxide Bi doping Oxygen vacancies Surface reactive oxygen species Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Stemming from worldwide concerns about human health and the natural environment, extensive efforts have been made to treat detrimental volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from our daily life and industry [1,2]. Among multi-pronged elimination methods [3,4], catalytic oxidation, the most thorough and eco-friendly one, catches significant attention, which not only converts VOCs into nontoxic CO2 and H2O molecules but also achieves energy recycling by using regenerative catalytic oxidors [5–7]. On the other hand, CH3OH, as one of the VOCs, the removal of which garners interest in the field of hydrogen energy due to the need for heat supply and treatment of tail gas for methanol steam reforming to hydrogen [5,6,8]. The key to efficient catalytic oxidation lies in the development of cost-effective catalysts [9]. Currently, the catalysts for thermal CH3OH oxidation can be divided into two categories: i) Pt, Pd, Ru, Au, or Ag-based noble metal catalysts [10–14]; and ii) transition metal-based (Mn, Cu, Ce, Co, etc.) oxide catalysts [15–18]. Transition metal oxides, especially Mn oxides, stand out and are widely investigated in virtue of low cost, abundant reserves, rich crystal structures, multi-valence states, excellent redox nature, superior lattice oxygen mobility, and high oxygen storage capacity, which promotes VOCs incineration for commercialization [19,20]. To further improve performances for catalytic oxidation reactions, a series of metal-doped manganese oxide catalysts have been studied. For instance, Wang et al. [21] synthesized Co-doped manganese oxides via microwave/ultrasound-assisted method to create polycrystalline interfacial sites for methane oxidation. Jiang et al. [22] reported that optimized Mn5Cu1 exhibited excellent catalytic oxidation performance with outstanding H2O resistance due to the bimetal synergistic effect and plentiful oxygen vacancies. Defect-rich manganese oxides can provide highly active sites for adsorption or activation of reactants and prompt conversion of intermediates [23,24]. It is worth mentioning that Bi doping has been widely applied in electrocatalytic, photocatalytic, and thermocatalytic oxidation reactions due to its promotion of lattice distortion defects and enhancement of redox capacity [25–27]. Bi-modified reducible metal oxides (Co3O4, Fe2O3, or CeO2) have been reported to be favorable for soot or CO oxidation [28–31]. To the best of our knowledge, systematic investigations on the structure-activity relationship of Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts for CH3OH oxidation are still inadequate. In the present study, we systematically studied the structure-activity relationship of Bi-doped MnO2 for CH3OH oxidation. In particular, X-ray diffraction (XRD), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), scanning electron microscope-energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (SEM-EDS), and quasi in situ X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (quasi in situ XPS) were used to characterize the bulk/surface structures of Bi-doped MnO2. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), oxygen or methanol temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD or CH3OH-TPD) were carried out to investigate the redox capability. In addition, CH3OH oxidation mechanism was revealed by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS). Bi doping facilitated the generation of oxygen vacancies to adsorb and activate O2 to produce surface reactive oxygen species. The conversions of methoxy species to formate, and formate to CO2 and H2O were accelerated. The promotion of H2O towards CH3OH oxidation was also investigated over Bi-doped MnO2, where hydroxyl species were found to assist CH3OH chemisorption and C-H activation of methoxy species with surface reactive oxygen species. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Raw materials and chemicals All the chemicals were of analytical grade. K2CO3 and Bi(CH3COO)3 were bought from Shanghai D&B Biological Science and Technology Co., Ltd. Mn(CH3COO)2·4 H2O were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. HOCH2CH2OH and CH3OH were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. SiO2 (40–50 mesh) were acquired from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Deionized water was homemade using the water purification system (electrical resistivity ≥ 18.25 MΩ·cm). Shanghai Air Liquide Co., Ltd. provided ultra-pure Air(20 %O2/80 %N2), Ar, 10 %H2/Ar, 2 %CO/98 %Ar, and CO2. All the chemicals were utilized without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of the Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts A low-temperature co-precipitation method was used to prepare Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts with different compositions. Mn(CH3COO)2·4 H2O and Bi(CH3COO)3 were stoichiometrically dispersed and dissolved in glycol (150 mL) following vigorous stirring for 1 h. And K2CO3 (0.0260 mol) was dissolved in deionized water (100 mL) under ultrasonication. Subsequently, the K2CO3 solution was injected at a rate of 4 mL·min−1 into the above bimetallic precursor solution with constant stirring and cooled with an ice bath. After complete injection, the suspensions were further aged for 2 h. The precipitates were then centrifugally washed with cold-deionized water until the pH reached 7.0, dried in an oven at 35 °C for 24 h, and calcined in static air at 450 °C for 4 h with a ramp rate of 2 °C·min−1. The detailed reagents and dosages of catalyst preparation were shown in Table S1. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by a series of methods, including O2-TPD, H2O temperature programmed desorption (H2O-TPD), CH3OH-TPD, H2-TPR, XRD, inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, HR-TEM, SEM-EDS, quasi in situ XPS, and in situ DRIFTS. Details of these operations were listed below. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm curves were tested using Micrometrics ASAP 2460 at −196 °C in static mode. Prior to characterization, the powder catalysts were thoroughly ground and degassed with pure He at 200 °C for 8 h. The specific surface area, total pore volume, average pore diameter, and pore size distribution were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) theories based on the adsorption branch of isotherm. XRD was performed with D8/Advance X-ray diffractometer (BRUKER, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). The scan range was 10–80°, the scan speed was 3 °·min−1, and the step size was 0.02°. The average grain sizes of manganese oxide substrates were calculated with the full width of half-maximum using the Scherrer formula: (1) D = 0.9 λ ∆ cos θ Where D is the crystal size, λ is the wavelength of X-rays, Δ is the FWHM of the diffraction peak, and θ is the angle corresponding to the peak. ICP-OES (Agilent 5800) was utilized to obtain the Mn, Bi, and K mass fractions, ensuring that the molar ratios of the samples synthesized were consistent with expectations. Using a micro-fixed bed reactor with a U-type quartz tube (4 mm diameter) connected to mass spectrometry (HIDEN HPR200) for online chemical detection, O2-TPD experiments were carried out. First of all, 50 mg of catalysts were treated with Ar (30 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h to remove adsorbed water and carbonate species. The reactor was then allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, and the flow gas was switched to 10 %O2/Ar (30 mL·min−1) to achieve oxygen adsorption on the catalysts. Subsequently, the flow gas was switched back to Ar (30 mL·min−1) to remove physically adsorbed O2 and stabilize the baseline. Finally, the temperature was programmed to increase from 25 to 840 °C with a ramp of 10 °C·min−1 in Argon atmosphere. The CH3OH-TPD or H2O-TPD process was similar to the O2-TPD, but the CH3OH (1 vol%) or H2O (3 vol%) was used instead of the 10 %O2. What’s more, the detected chemicals were CH3OH, CO2, and H2O, respectively. And more attention was paid to the results below 400 °C. During H2-TPR operation, 10 %H2/Ar was introduced after pretreating and cooling. Once the baseline stabilized for 1.5 h, the temperature program was run from 25 to 740 °C with a ramp of 10 °C·min−1. Quasi in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was detected on Thermo Fisher Scientific-K-Alpha spectrometer equipped with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV, pass energy 50.0 eV). The C 1 s peak (284.8 eV, as reference) was adopted to calibrate all the binding energy. Before the examination, catalysts were pretreated in Ar (30 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h and transferred into a vacuum analysis chamber to avoid exposure to air. The XPS spectra of Mn 2p3/2, Mn 3 s, Bi 4 f, and O 1 s were recorded. HR-TEM was conducted on a JEOL JEM F200 microscope operated at 100 kV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements were performed using a TESCAN MIRA LMS. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was measured with Quantax 200 XFlash 6|60. In situ DRIFTS spectra of CH3OH oxidation and CH3OH-TPD processes at elevated temperatures were recorded using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Frontier) equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT-A) detector and a homemade in situ cell (Fig. S1) [32] with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Firstly, 50 mg of catalysts were pretreated by an Ar flow (30 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h and cooled to 15 °C. Then, the background spectrum was recorded. In the CH3OH oxidation process, spectra over MnO2, BiOx, and Mn7.5Bi1Ox were obtained with the samples heated to 300 or 500 °C at a rate of 5 °C·min−1 in 1 %CH3OH/10 %O2/40 %N2/Ar atmosphere. Moreover, H2O (3 vol%) was added to investigate its influence where needed. In the CH3OH-TPD process over MnO2 and Mn7.5Bi1Ox, the catalysts were pretreated with Ar (30 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h and cooled to 15 °C, and then the reactants with 1 %CH3OH/Ar (30 mL·min−1) were introduced for 1 h to adsorb CH3OH, and the catalysts were purged with Ar. The spectra were recorded at an Ar flow (30 mL·min−1) with temperature increasing at a ramp of 5 °C·min−1. The infrared absorption peaks of the intermediate species were integrated and the distributions of the peak area with temperature were plotted. 2.4 Evaluation of catalytic performance The catalysts were applied to catalytic CH3OH oxidation, CO oxidation, and CH3OH cracking reactions. Details of these evaluations of catalytic performance were listed below. The catalyst evaluation setup (Fig. S2) for CH3OH oxidation was a micro-fixed bed reactor, where 40 mg of catalysts (60–80 mesh) diluted with 160 mg of SiO2 (40–50 mesh) were sandwiched by quartz wool within the quartz tube (4 mm diameter). Constant CH3OH was introduced by air bubbling through a glass saturator at −4 °C and further mixed with Ar. The chromatographic results up to 100 h demonstrated the stability of CH3OH bubbling (Fig. S3). The inlet was a gas mixture of 1 %CH3OH/10 %O2/40 %N2/Ar with a total flow rate of 30 mL·min−1. The corresponding weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 45000 mL· g cat . − 1 · h − 1 . The reactor effluents were analyzed by gas chromatographs (Shanghai Ruimin, Model GC2006) equipped with a capillary column of KB-1301, a 5 A molecular sieves column, a TDX-01 column, a methanizer, a flame ionization detector (FID), and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for analysis of the products. Both the inlet streamlines from bubbler to reactor and the outlet streamlines from reactor to gas chromatograph were heated at 100 °C to avoid condensation of the chemicals. The effect of H2O (3, 5, 10, and 15 vol%) or CO2 (3 vol%) on CH3OH oxidation was also explored. To diminish the significant influence of heat and mass transfer, the conversion of CH3OH was kept below 20 % using 1.00 mg of catalysts diluted with 4.00 mg of SiO2 to obtain the reaction rate ( R CH 3 OH ) and apparent activation energy (Ea). The conversion of CH3OH ( X CH 3 OH , %) is calculated using Eq. (2): (2) X CH 3 OH % = C CH 3 OH in − C CH 3 OH out C CH 3 OH in × 100 % Where C CH 3 OH in and C CH 3 OH out are the inlet and outlet concentrations of CH3OH, respectively. The yield of CO2 ( Y CO 2 , %) is calculated from the Eq. (3): (3) Y CO 2 = C CO 2 out C CH 3 OH in × 100 % Where C CO 2 out is the outlet concentration of CO2. The rate of CH3OH oxidation ( R CH 3 OH , μ mol CH 3 OH · g cat . − 1 · s − 1 ) is calculated by Eq. (4): (4) R CH 3 OH μ mol CH 3 OH · g cat . − 1 · s − 1 = F CH 3 OH × X CH 3 OH m cat . Where F CH 3 OH is the flow rate of CH3OH in μmol·s−1, m cat. is the catalyst weight in grams. The specific rate of CH3OH oxidation based on the specific surface areas ( R S , μ mol CH 3 OH · m − 2 · s − 1 ) is calculated by Eq. (5): (5) R S μ mol CH 3 OH · m − 2 · s − 1 = F CH 3 OH × X CH 3 OH m cat . × A S Where A S is the specific surface area of catalysts in m2·g−1. The Arrhenius Eq. (6) is utilized to obtain the apparent activation energy ( E a , kJ ∙ mol − 1 ) of catalysts for CH3OH oxidation with CH3OH conversion below 20 %. (6) ln R CH 3 OH = − E a RT + ln A Where R is the ideal gas constant (8.314 J ∙ mol − 1 ∙ K − 1 ), T is the reaction temperature (K), and A is the pre-exponential factor. Ultimately, the apparent activation energy was calculated by plotting ln R CH 3 OH ∼ 1000/T. CO oxidation was performed using the identical setup and pretreatment. The inlet was a gas mixture of 1 %CO/10 %O2/40 %N2/Ar with a total flow rate of 30 mL·min−1. The influence of H2O (3 and 15 vol%) was also examined on CO oxidation. The conversion of CO (X CO, %) is calculated by Eq. (7): (7) X CO % = C CO 2 out C CO out + C CO 2 out Where C CO out and C CO 2 out are the outlet concentrations of CO and CO2, respectively. CH3OH cracking was performed using the identical setup and pretreatment. The inlet was a gas mixture of 1 %CH3OH/Ar with a total flow rate of 30 mL·min−1. The yield of CO (Y CO, %) is calculated by Eq. (8): (8) Y CO % = C CO out C CH 3 OH in Where C CO out is the outlet concentration of CO and C CH 3 OH in is the inlet concentration of CH3OH. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Activity of Bi-doped MnO2 towards CH3OH oxidation To systematically investigate the role of Bi doping in MnO2, catalysts with varying Bi doping were synthesized, with the actual content confirmed by ICP-OES analysis (Table S2). The CH3OH oxidation activities over Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts ( Fig. 1a,b and S4) followed the order of Mn7.5Bi1Ox > Mn15Bi1Ox > Mn2.5Bi1Ox > MnO2 > BiOx. The T50 (the temperature at which 50 %CH3OH converted) was noticed at 147 °C for Mn7.5Bi1Ox, which was remarkably lower than that for MnO2 (165 °C), Mn15Bi1Ox (152 °C), Mn2.5Bi1Ox (154 °C), and BiOx (300 °C), respectively. Specifically, at 160 °C, Mn7.5Bi1Ox achieved almost 90 % CO2 yield, while MnO2, Mn15Bi1Ox, Mn2.5Bi1Ox, and BiOx reached 25, 70, 69, and 0 % CO2 yield. The CH3OH reaction rates were also calculated, showing a volcanic trend against the amount of Bi over Bi-doped MnO2 (Fig. S5). The CH3OH reaction rate of the Mn7.5Bi1Ox was 14.2 μ mol C H 3 O H · g cat . − 1 · s − 1 at 150 °C, which was 1.5 times that of MnO2. At 160 °C, R CH 3 OH over Mn7.5Bi1Ox raised to 20.5 μ mol C H 3 O H · g cat . − 1 · s − 1 , being 2 times that of the unpromoted MnO2. The influence of weight hourly space velocities was explored (Fig. S6), where Mn7.5Bi1Ox manifested satisfactory activity even at 180000 mL·g−1·h−1. To the best of our knowledge, this is among the highly active catalysts that have been reported for CH3OH oxidation (Table S3). Mn7.5Bi1Ox also performed well in the stability test of catalytic CH3OH oxidation at 165 °C for up to 100 h with CH3OH conversion and CO2 yield decreasing by only ∼7 % compared to ∼11 and ∼17 % for MnO2 (Fig. 1c). In addition, Arrhenius plots of these catalysts during CH3OH oxidation in the temperature region of 110–190 °C were presented in Fig. 1d, where the apparent activation energy followed the order of Mn7.5Bi1Ox (Ea = 42.9 ± 1.6 kJ·mol−1) < Mn2.5Bi1Ox (Ea = 53.0 ± 3.9 kJ·mol−1) < Mn15Bi1Ox (Ea = 56.6 ± 3.6 kJ·mol−1) < MnO2 (Ea = 72.1 ± 4.3 kJ·mol−1). The lowest Ea of Mn7.5Bi1Ox indicated that CH3OH oxidation was more kinetically favorable. H2O, as the target product of catalytic CH3OH oxidation, might be tightly adsorbed on the active sites of catalysts, especially for Mn-based catalysts, which leads to a sharp decrease in catalytic VOCs oxidation activity [24,33]. Exceptionally, the presence of H2O (3, 5, 10, and 15 vol%) resulted in a slight enhancement of CH3OH oxidation ( Fig. 2a,b). In addition, the catalytic stability of MnO2 and Mn7.5Bi1Ox for CH3OH oxidation under high humidity (10 vol%) at 140 °C was conducted (Fig. S7). The CH3OH conversion increased slightly over MnO2 and Mn7.5Bi1Ox with H2O (10 vol%) introduced midway. When H2O molecules were removed, the CH3OH conversion slightly decreased to the previous levels. We also conducted CO oxidation experiments with H2O (0, 3, and 15 vol%) at 140 °C, CO conversion (Fig. S8) over Mn7.5Bi1Ox declined from 91 % to 60 % and then to 43 %, while over MnO2, it decreased from 78 % to 39 % and then to 30 %. Hence, H2O molecules exhibited inhibition on CO oxidation over Bi-doped MnO2·H2O-TPD experiments (Fig. S9) were performed on MnO2 and Mn7.5Bi1Ox in the temperature range (50–250 °C). Bi doping weakened H2O adsorption on MnO2 and the H2O molecules adsorption peak areas were reduced by 25 %. Differences in the H2O-tolerance of Bi-doped MnO2 between CH3OH oxidation and CO oxidation reactions might provide indirect information on the mechanism of CH3OH oxidation, which would be discussed later in this work. After introducing CO2 (3 vol%), the CH3OH conversion and CO2 yield declined slightly (Fig. 2c,d). This might be due to the formation of carbonate species from CO2 adsorbed on the active surface sites, which in turn affect the activity [18,33,34]. 3.2 Bulk structure and morphology of Bi-doped MnO2 The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms (Fig. S10) were executed to determine the pore size distributions and specific surface areas of Bi-doped MnO2 (Table S4). All the samples displayed Ⅳ isotherms with hysteresis loops, indicating a typical mesoporous structure of the catalysts [35]. The specific surface areas of the samples followed the order of MnO2 (105.5 m2·g−1) > Mn15Bi1Ox (101.1 m2·g−1) > Mn7.5Bi1Ox (77.9 m2·g−1) > Mn2.5Bi1Ox (40.5 m2·g−1) > BiOx (1.2 m2·g−1). Similarly, the total pore volumes of the samples followed the order: MnO2 (0.314 cm3·g−1) > Mn15Bi1Ox (0.258 cm3·g−1) > Mn7.5Bi1Ox (0.196 cm3·g−1) > Mn2.5Bi1Ox (0.158 cm3·g−1) > BiOx (0.003 cm3·g−1). The average pore diameter showed a reverse-volcano trend against the amount of Bi: MnO2 (11.9 nm) > Mn15Bi1Ox (9.1 nm) > Mn7.5Bi1Ox (8.9 nm) < Mn2.5Bi1Ox (14.4 nm) < BiOx (14.8 nm). RS were calculated by correlating CH3OH oxidation rate and specific surface areas at 130 °C ( Fig. 3a), which followed the order of MnO2 (0.019 μ mol CH 3 OH · m − 2 · s − 1 ) < Mn15Bi1Ox (0.049 μ mol CH 3 OH · m − 2 · s − 1 ) < Mn2.5Bi1Ox (0.067 μ mol CH 3 OH · m − 2 · s − 1 ) < Mn7.5Bi1Ox (0.093 μ mol CH 3 OH · m − 2 · s − 1 ). The specific reaction rates were related to the content of surface active sites. In general, large specific surface area can expose more active sites, thereby increasing the probability of reactant contact and ultimately facilitating the reaction. However, MnO2 with the largest specific surface area exhibited the lowest specific reaction rate, which indicated that the surface area might not be the dominant factor in catalytic activity [36]. The pore structures might be related to the compositions, but didn’t influence the internal diffusion. We carried out the CH3OH oxidation over Mn7.5Bi1Ox with different mesh sizes, which didn’t exhibit significant changes (Fig. S11). XRD analyses were performed to obtain crystal structure information of the catalysts (Fig. 3b). For unpromoted MnO2, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 36.9, 56.0, and 67.4° were consistent with (100), (102), and (110) crystal planes of hexagonal MnO2 (PDF #89–5171). The MnCO3 (PDF #85–1109) phase was present in minute quantities with peaks at 31.7° corresponding to the (104) crystal plane due to its incomplete thermal decomposition for MnO2 [37]. The XRD patterns of BiOx could be well indexed with monoclinic Bi2O3 (PDF #71–0465), where the sharp peaks (2θ = 24.4, 25.6, 26.7, 27.2, 27.8, 33.1, and 46.2°) coincided with the (-102), (002), (111), (120), (012), (121), and (122) planes. The average grain size of BiOx was ∼68.6 nm based on Scherrer formula [29]. With Bi doped into MnO2, the peak (36.9°) of MnO2 shifted towards lower 2θ values by ∼0.3°, implying that Bi atoms were doped into the manganese oxide lattice and caused lattice expansion. In addition, referring to the weaker peak and the broader full width of half-maximum of crystal phase at (100) crystal planes of MnO2, the crystallinity decreased and the average grain sizes of MnO2 substrates in these catalysts were calculated by Scherrer formula, which followed the order of MnO2 (8.6 nm) > Mn15Bi1Ox (7.9 nm) > Mn7.5Bi1Ox (7.5 nm). Furthermore, the orthorhombic Bi2Mn4O10 (PDF #74–1096) crystal phase recognizably appeared over Mn2.5Bi1Ox [38]. TEM and HR-TEM images of MnO2, Mn7.5Bi1Ox, and BiOx were taken to investigate their crystal structures (Figs. 3c-3e and S12). MnO2 presented the lattice spacings of 0.213 and 0.247 nm (Fig. 3c), corresponding to the (101) and (100) lattice planes of MnO2. The irregular structures and unclear lattice fringes of Mn7.5Bi1Ox (Fig. 3d and S12e) demonstrated their low crystallinity and abundant lattice defects, while the lattice fringes of MnO2 (100) in some places could be observed slightly. The SEM images and elemental mapping of Mn7.5Bi1Ox exhibited well-dispersed Bi over sphere MnO2 [33] (Fig. S13). The quantified surface Mn/Bi atom ratio was 9.97, slightly lower than the theoretical value (Table S5). The residual alkali metal (K, potassium) based on the quantified EDS spectrum on the Mn7.5Bi1Ox surface was considerably low (0.03 wt%). Moreover, residual K contents over MnO2 and Mn7.5Bi1Ox based on the ICP-OES results were determined to be 0.08 and 0.10 wt% (Table S2), the influence of which could be neglected under such low and similar contents [39]. For BiOx, the exposed lattice fringes (Fig. 3e) of 0.236, 0.317, and 0.390 nm agreed well with the interplanar distances of the (112), (012), and (020) facets of Bi2O3. And its visualized large grain size (Fig. S12c) was consistent with XRD results (grain size based on the Scherrer formula: ∼68.6 nm). 3.3 Surface chemical structure and adsorption properties of Bi-doped MnO2 Quasi in situ XPS analyses were performed to investigate the chemical states of Bi-doped MnO2 ( Fig. 4). The peaks in the Mn 2p3/2 spectra (Fig. 4a) at ∼641.8 eV belonged to Mn 2p3/2, which could be deconvoluted into peaks of Mn4+, Mn3+, and Mn2+, respectively [18,33]. The Mn3+/Mn4+ surface atomic ratios were calculated based on peak areas (Table S6), which followed the order of MnO2 (0.533) < Mn2.5Bi1Ox (0.838) < Mn15Bi1Ox (0.857) < Mn7.5Bi1Ox (1.185). It is generally accepted that the Mn3+/Mn4+ redox pairs are associated with the content of oxygen vacancies (OV) based on the electrostatic balance ( 2 Mn 4 + + O 2 − → 2 Mn 3 + + O V + 1 / 2 O 2 ) [40]. The average oxidation valences (AOS) of Mn were also calculated using the empirical formula ( AOS = 9.27 − 1.18 × Δ Ε ) based on the Mn 3 s multiple energy (ΔΕ) [33,41,42]. The ΔΕ of MnO2, Mn15Bi1Ox, Mn7.5Bi1Ox, and Mn2.5Bi1Ox were 5.02, 5.25, 5.43, and 5.30 eV, whose AOS were 3.34, 3.07, 2.86, and 3.01 (Fig. 4b and Table S6). Thus, Mn7.5Bi1Ox possessed the most unsaturated Mn atoms accompanied with abundant oxygen vacancy defects, which were attributed to Bi doping. The peaks of Bi 4 f spectra at ∼164.0 and ∼158.8 eV corresponded to the Bi 4f5/2 and Bi 4f7/2 with ∼5.3 eV gap (Fig. 4c), respectively. Pure Bi2O3 has peaks located at 163.8 and 158.4 eV in line with the literature [38,43]. With Bi doped into MnO2, the peaks shifted to 164.1 and 158.9 eV over Mn15Bi1Ox, while shifted by only ∼0.2 eV towards high binding energy over Mn7.5Bi1Ox and Mn2.5Bi1Ox, which could be attributed to the electron interaction between Bi and Mn [27] and the incorporation of Bi into the crystal lattice of MnO2 [44]. For the O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4d), the peaks at ∼529.7 eV were assigned to the lattice oxygen species (Oα); the peaks at ∼531.5 eV were assigned to the surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oβ, including O-, O2 -, and O2 2-) and the peaks at ∼533.3 eV belonged to the surface adsorbed H2O (Oγ) [24,37,45,46]. The ratio of Oα over Bi-doped MnO2 followed the reverse-volcanic order of MnO2 (62.5 %) > Mn15Bi1Ox (60.8 %) > Mn7.5Bi1Ox (53.5 %) < Mn2.5Bi1Ox (59.7 %) with Bi content, while the ratio of Oβ (Table S6) followed the volcanic order of MnO2 (35.9 %) < Mn15Bi1Ox (37.7 %) < Mn7.5Bi1Ox (45.3 %) > Mn2.5Bi1Ox (39.5 %). Under the influence of Bi doping, the reduction of lattice oxygen species indicated the facile formation of surface oxygen vacancies, which in turn promoted O2 adsorption and activation to form active surface adsorbed oxygen species in the Air atmosphere [18,28–31,47]. Moreover, the ratio of surface adsorbed H2O (Oγ) exhibited a declining trend with Bi content, which followed the order of Mn2.5Bi1Ox (0.8 %) < Mn7.5Bi1Ox (1.2 %) < Mn15Bi1Ox (1.5 %) < MnO2 (1.6 %). Such low ratios were due to the pretreatment (in 30 mL·min−1 Ar flow at 200 °C for 1 h). O2-TPD ( Fig. 5a) was executed to investigate the mobility and content distribution of oxygen species. The desorption peaks were divided into three temperature ranges: i) below 200 °C, ii) 200–400 °C, and iii) above 400 °C, which were attributed to the desorption of i) physically adsorbed oxygen species, ii) chemically adsorbed oxygen species, and iii) lattice oxygen species, respectively [24,33]. It was worth mentioning that Bi2O3 had almost no desorption of oxygen species in line with the literature [29]. In comparison, the desorption peaks of oxygen species over MnO2 were located at 427 °C. With Bi doped into MnO2, the desorption temperature of oxygen species over Bi-doped MnO2 decreased to 404, 366, and 404 °C. The content of chemically adsorbed oxygen species (Table S6) followed the order of MnO2 (10.6 %) < Mn15Bi1Ox (14.1 %) < Mn7.5Bi1Ox (16.8 %) > Mn2.5Bi1Ox (15.6 %). In this sense, Mn7.5Bi1Ox possessed superior oxygen species mobility and rich chemically adsorbed oxygen species. Bi doping enhanced the favorable oxygen species mobility and facilitated the formation of oxygen vacancies over MnO2, which promoted O2 adsorption and activation and increased the content of reactive chemically adsorbed oxygen species, thereby promoting CH3OH oxidation [20,24,48]. H2-TPR (Fig. 5b) was carried out to evaluate the reducibility of catalysts. The peak temperature over MnO2 and BiOx were 248 and 480 °C [29,38,47]. Once the Bi atoms were doped into the MnO2, the reduction peak temperatures shifted to 223, 180, and 337 °C over Mn15Bi1Ox, Mn7.5Bi1Ox, and Mn2.5Bi1Ox, promoting the reducibility of the catalysts, which might be related to the reduced MnO2 particle sizes. CH3OH-TPD (Fig. 5c) was also performed with CH3OH and CO2 monitored to evaluate CH3OH desorption and reaction processes. The peaks for CH3OH desorption at ∼80 °C were ascribed to physically adsorbed CH3OH. The following peaks of CO2 corresponded to the oxidation of chemically adsorbed CH3OH by surface adsorbed oxygen species and lattice oxygen. The peak temperature for CO2 production followed the order of Mn7.5Bi1Ox (146 °C) < Mn2.5Bi1Ox (153 °C) < Mn15Bi1Ox (157 °C) < MnO2 (169 °C) < BiOx (305 °C), which was in line with their catalytic activities towards CH3OH oxidation. 3.4 Structure-activity relationship of Bi-doped MnO2 during CH3OH oxidation In situ DRIFT experiments were conducted over MnO2, BiOx, and Mn7.5Bi1Ox to get insight into the role of Bi doping during CH3OH oxidation ( Fig. 6). The catalysts were pretreated with Ar (30 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h and cooled to 15 °C to record the background. Then, reactants (1 %CH3OH/10 %O2/40 %N2/Ar, 30 mL·min−1) were introduced into the cell. After the adsorption saturation of reactants, the spectra were recorded in reactants with elevated temperature at a rate of 5 °C·min−1. The assignments of the vibration characteristic peaks are enumerated in Table S7 based on the literature [18,33,49–54]. The peaks at 3500–3700 and 1610–1640 cm−1 might be ascribed to hydroxyl species (-OH). The bands at ∼2926 and ∼2820 cm−1 belong to νas(C-H) and νs(C-H) of the methoxy species (-OCH3). The features at ∼1030 cm−1 can be assigned to ν(C-O) mode of the methoxy species (-OCH3). The characteristic peaks at ∼1590 and ∼1310 cm−1 correspond to νas(-OCO) and νs(-OCO) of formate species, respectively. The peaks at ∼2170 and ∼2110 cm−1 belong to CO. Two peaks at ∼2360 and ∼2320 cm−1 might be identified as CO2. To visualize the evolution of the species, the infrared absorption peaks of the species were integrated and the evolution of the peak area with temperature was plotted (Fig. 6b,d,f,h). The CH3OH oxidation reactants adsorbed on MnO2 at 15 °C (Fig. 6a,b) resulted in the observed peaks at 2926, 2820, and 1030 cm⁻¹ corresponding to the methoxy species [55]. As the temperature increased, the intensity of formate species (νas(-OCO) at 1580 cm−1) gradually enhanced from 50 °C and reached a maximum at 175 °C [52]. CO₂ peaks at 2361 and 2320 cm⁻¹ were observed from 175 °C [56], illustrating the further oxidation of formate species. For the BiOx catalysts, methoxy species were observed upon saturated adsorption of reactants (Fig. 6c,d). The intensity of formate species (νas(-OCO) at 1580 cm−1) started to enhance from 100 °C and reached a maximum at 215 °C [52]. CO2 started to appear from the oxidation of formate species at 250 °C. For Mn7.5Bi1Ox, the formate species emerged at 50 °C, reaching the maximum at 150 °C, and further started to be oxidized to CO2 and H2O simultaneously (Fig. 6e,f). It is widely recognized that formate is the key intermediate during CH3OH oxidation, and its generation from methoxy species and further conversion are important [53,54]. Comparatively, the temperature of the maximum formate species peak areas followed the order of Mn7.5Bi1Ox (150 °C) < MnO2 (175 °C) < BiOx (215 °C) and the onset temperature of enhanced CO2 peaks also followed the same order of Mn7.5Bi1Ox (150 °C) < MnO2 (175 °C) < BiOx (250 °C), demonstrating that two oxidation processes were accelerated over Bi-doped MnO2 due to surface reactive oxygen species. Furthermore, a few studies have shown the presence of CO during CH3OH oxidation [18,51]. CO peaks (at 2170 and 2110 cm−1) were barely observed in the spectra. CH3OH Cracking was also carried out over Mn7.5Bi1Ox (Fig. S14). It was found that CO did not begin to slightly produce until 260 °C. In this sense, formate species could be directly oxidized to CO2 and H2O, rather than decomposing to H2O and CO, which was then oxidized to CO2. Based on the above results, a probable mechanism of CH3OH oxidation is proposed, following the pathway: CH3OH → methoxy species → formate species → CO2 and H2O, which is consistent with the literature [54,57,58]. H2O molecules have been reported to promote CH3OH oxidation [50,59]. Two functions of hydroxyl species were reported in the literature: i) the hydroxyl species assisted CH3OH chemisorption via hydrogen bonding [18,55,58]; ii) the hydroxyl species assisted C-H activation of methoxy species with surface reactive oxygen species [50,60]. To reveal the effect of hydroxyl species, the Mn7.5Bi1Ox was pretreated with Ar (30 mL·min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h and cooled to room temperature. And then, 1 %CH3OH/Ar was introduced for full adsorption. Finally, in situ DRIFTS were recorded for CH3OH desorption at room temperature with Ar (30 mL·min−1) purging (Fig. S15). The peaks of methoxy species (at 2926, 2820, and 1030 cm−1) gradually diminished, accompanied with enhanced peaks of hydroxyl species (3500–3700 cm−1) within 20 mins, which demonstrated that the CH3OH adsorption was related to the hydroxyl species. Moreover, in situ DRIFTS of CH3OH oxidation with H2O addition over Mn7.5Bi1Ox were performed (Fig. 6g,h). After the same pretreatment, the reactants with H2O (3 vol%) were constantly introduced and the spectra were recorded at elevated temperature (5 °C·min−1). The peaks (-OH) from H2O hydrolysis (at ∼3500 and ∼1640 cm−1) significantly appeared at 15 °C and gradually faded away with temperature increasing, illustrating the participation of -OH in CH3OH oxidation. The whole reaction mechanism did not change much; it still evolved from CH3OH to methoxy species, subsequently to formate species, and ultimately to CO2 and H2O. However, the production of formate species sharply sped up from 50 °C and reached the maximum at 140 °C, lower than that (150 °C) during dry CH3OH oxidation. The hydroxyl species could take part in CH3OH chemisorption and the C-H activation of methoxy species, the oxidation of which was subsequently accelerated into formate species by surrounding reactive oxygen species [18,50,58]. Based on the above studies, the structure-activity relationship of MnO2 with the addition of Bi towards CH3OH oxidation can be established. In our study, the T50 (the temperature at which 50 %CH3OH converted) of BiOx towards CH3OH oxidation was 300 °C (Fig. S4), much higher than MnO2 (165 °C) and Mn7.5Bi1Ox (147 °C) (Fig. 1a). In the XRD pattern of Mn7.5Bi1Ox, the peaks of BiOx (Bi2O3) and MnO2 could be observed simultaneously (Fig. 3b). However, the worst activity, weak oxygen and methanol desorption peaks over BiOx (Figs. 5a and 5c), indicated that the contribution from the synergistic effect of BiOx and MnO2 to CH3OH oxidation was weak or even negligible. Bi doping promoted CH3OH oxidation mainly by the Bi entering into the lattice of MnO2, leading to changes in lattice structure, surface chemical structure, and redox properties. Moreover, the synergistic effect of Bi and Mn ions in MnBiOx solid solutions was possible to exist, and it was worth further systematic studies to elucidate this mechanism. With Bi doped into MnO2 (the downshifted peaks), Bi primarily enters the lattice of MnO2, leading to the expansion of lattice spacing and a decrease in crystallinity (XRD and TEM results). As a result, the Mn7.5Bi1Ox catalyst contains abundant lattice defects in the form of oxygen vacancies. Such a structure with plenty of Mn3+/Mn4+ redox pairs shows more active surface adsorbed oxygen species (O2-TPD and CH3OH-TPD results), and consequently, reveals much improved catalytic performance towards CH3OH oxidation as compared to the unpromoted MnO2 catalyst. Furthermore, the dominant role of the surface area in improved activity was also excluded by the observation that MnO2 with the largest specific surface area presented the lowest specific reaction rate. The CH3OH oxidation mechanism is that CH3OH molecules adsorbed over the catalysts deprotonate to methoxy species, which are oxidized to formate species by surface reactive oxygen species located at oxygen vacancies. The resultant formate species are further oxidized by surface reactive oxygen species to CO2 and H2O. The exposed vacancies are replenished by gaseous O2 dissociation. Bi doping accelerates two oxidation steps by reactive oxygen species on oxygen vacancies. Jiang et al. [53] emphasized the importance of CH3OH and O2 adsorption during CH3OH oxidation over Pt1-Co3O4 by combining experiments and DFT calculations. To study the role of O2 during CH3OH oxidation, in situ CH3OH-TPD-DRIFTS was performed over MnO2 and Mn7.5Bi1Ox ( Fig. 7). The catalysts were pretreated in Ar at 200 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 15 °C to record the background. Afterward, 30 mL·min−1 of 1 %CH3OH/Ar was fed to the cell for 1 h. The catalysts were then heated to 300 °C at a rate of 5 °C·min−1 in Ar flow with the spectra recorded. For MnO2, the formate species increased slowly, and the maximum peak temperature shifted from 175 °C (with O2) to 182 °C (without O2). Due to the lack of gaseous O2 replenishment, it was difficult to observe CO2 originating from the deep oxidation of formate species. For Mn7.5Bi1Ox, the maximum peak of formate species slightly shifted from 150 °C (with O2) to 154 °C (without O2). Since there was no timely replenishment of gaseous O2, the oxidation of formate species to CO2 became slow as well, even with abundant surface reactive oxygen species. The replenishment and dissociation of O2 on oxygen vacancies were equally essential for the formation of surface reactive oxygen species, which were also emphasized in the literature [18,53,56,57]. In brief, the promotion mechanism of Bi-doped MnO2 is the formation of oxygen vacancies induced by Bi-doping, which facilitates the O2 adsorption and dissociation into active surface adsorbed oxygen species, accelerating the oxidation processes of methoxy species to formate species and formate species to CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusions In summary, multiple Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts were synthesized and systematically investigated to reveal the structure-activity relationship of Bi doping towards catalytic CH3OH oxidation. Bi doping induces a decrease in crystallinity and lattice expansion of MnO2. Meanwhile, abundant Mn3+/Mn4+ redox pairs and unsaturated Mn emerge, accompanied with oxygen vacancies due to Bi doping, which are conducive to adsorbing and activating O2 to generate more active surface adsorbed oxygen species. During CH3OH oxidation, the oxidation processes from methoxy species to formate species and from formate species to CO2 and H2O over Bi-doped MnO2 are significantly expedited due to the rich and active surface oxygen species. It is worth mentioning that H2O molecules can, to some extent, facilitate CH3OH oxidation via hydroxyl-assisted CH3OH chemisorption and hydroxyl-assisted C-H activation of methoxy species with surface reactive oxygen species. The findings in this work have the potential to deepen the understanding and guide the design of catalysts with rich oxygen vacancies via metal doping methods for catalytic oxidation. coredata.dc:description: MnO2-based catalysts have been extensively utilized in the catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds due to their cost-effectiveness. In this study, a series of Bi-doped MnO2 catalysts with various contents were systematically investigated to reveal the structure-activity relationship during the CH3OH oxidation reaction, which was achieved using a series of characterizations. Bi could enter the MnO2 lattice and lead to the facile formation of oxygen vacancies, facilitating the generation of surface reactive oxygen species by O2 dissociation. With the increase of Bi, the activity showed a volcanic trend, and the Mn7.5Bi1Ox (T90 = 160 °C) exhibited the lowest apparent activation energy and optimal performance. CH3OH oxidation mechanism (CH3OH → methoxy species → formate species → CO2 and H2O) was revealed by in situ DRIFTS, and the last two oxidation processes were significantly sped up. Bi-doped MnO2 exhibited high H2O tolerance due to hydroxyl-assisted CH3OH chemisorption via hydrogen bonding and hydroxyl-assisted C-H activation of methoxy species with surface reactive oxygen species. These findings are beneficial for the rational design of metal-doped catalysts with rich oxygen vacancy defects for catalytic oxidation.
